!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The superlative / Der Superlativ!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In lesson 4 you learned the comparative form of the adjective. Remember:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The superlative is the highest degree of comparison. It is regular in formation and occurs, for example, in combination with !!?i?!!sein!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. In this case the superlative is more independent. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! The adjective in combination with !!?i?!!sein!!?/i?!!:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The superlative is always indicated by !!?i?!!am!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!-sten!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! . !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!If the adjective ends in an !!?i?!!s!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! sound (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!groß!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!), the !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!s!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is omitted.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! Besides these regularly formed comparatives, there are also irregular forms. There are three important forms which you must try to learn:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Examples:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Main clause and subordinate clause!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Until now we have looked at simple sentences. For all that the language is structured. There are structures which have precedence and those which are subordinate. Main clauses have precedence, and subordinating clauses are subordinated. We are dealing now with compound sentences. main clause main clause |_________| subordinate clause or subordinate clause !!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Common, important conjunctions!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!A subordinate clause is usually introduced by a word which combines two or more sentence parts (clauses): a conjunction.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The conjunction wenn!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Subordinate clauses introduced by “wenn!!?i?!!”!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! give a condition for what is said in the main clause.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Did you recognise the rule for the word order? In subordinate clauses, which are introduced by a conjunction, the finite verb stands at the end of the sentence.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!A preceding subordinate clause occupies the first position in the compound sentence. The finite verb of the main clause then follows as a rule in the 2nd position. 1st position2nd position .!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Note the position of !!?i?!!sich!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!, it is always placed near the beginning of the sentence: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!wenn sie sich freut ... !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The conjunction weil!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Subordinate clauses introduced by !!?i?!!weil !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!show a cause, a reason. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!Once again note the position of the finite verb in the subordinate and in the main clause:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The conjunction dass!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Subordinate clauses introduced by !!?i?!!dass!!?/i?!! show a completion of the meaning of the main clause. Also pay attention to the position of the finite verb here.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!A 2nd subordinate clause!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The 1st subordinate clause can be followed by a 2nd subordinate clause, which is then subordinated to the 1st.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!This is the sentence structure: the main clause has precedence, the 1st subordinate clause is subordinate to the main clause and given precedence over the 2nd subordinate clause, which then is subordinate to the 1st subordinate clause.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!main clause!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!subordinate clause 1!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!subordinate clause 2!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Conjunctions!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!There are coordinating conjunctions and subordinating conjunctions.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Coordinating conjunctions!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!A comma must be placed before sentences introduced by !!?i?!!aber!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! or !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!denn!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Subordinating conjunctions!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Subordinating clauses are separated from main clauses by a comma. You will get to know some other subordinating conjunctions in the following lessons.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Once again: The superlative / Der Superlativ!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In lesson 8 the superlative was described as an independent complement:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The superlative occurs also in other forms: as a noun attribute, which means: an adjective in the superlative qualifies a noun. For example:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!general, any film!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!specific film!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!general, any friend!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!specific friend!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Superlative adjectives are declined like all regular adjectives.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Examples for the three common, but irregular adjectives !!?i?!!gut, viel, gern!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The indefinite adjectives!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The articles !!?i?!!der, die. das!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! can be replaced by indefinite adjectives:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!They take the place of an article and have a special meaning:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!specific people, things!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!not many, many!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!without exception!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Indefinite adjectives are declined like adjectives.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The plural of !!?i?!!jeder, jede, jedes!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!alle!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The prepositions / Die Präpositionen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Prepositions are small words which establish a relation between big words such as verbs and nouns. This can be a local, temporal, or causal relation or other relations. local!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!temporal!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!causal!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Moreover some verbs are always combined with certain prepositions: either with one (!!?i?!!informieren über!!?/i?!!), with two (!!?i?!!reden mit/über!!?/i?!!), or even with three prepositions (!!?i?!!kämpfen für/um/gegen!!?/i?!!). It is necessary to learn the verbs and the prepositions they are combined with right from the start. These combinations of verb and preposition will be listed in the vocabulary section from this lesson onwards. Lessons 1 – 9 contain the following verbs with fixed prepositions (we list here only those prepositions which require the accusative):!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!You will notice that the prepositions have a particular characteristic: they determine the case of the noun and of the pronouns with which they form a word group.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Prepositions, which always require the accusative!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Some prepositions require the accusative or the dative case.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The accusative can require:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!!!?/i?!!and other prepositions!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Compare:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!(You will find the explanation in Lesson 11.)!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The accusative complement and the prepositional complement!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The verbs are not restricted to being used with only an accusative complement or only a prepositional complement. Both complements can be combined with the verb. For example: Accusative complement!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Prepositional complement!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Both complements!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The negative / Die Negation!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!You have already learned the negative, for example:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!!!?i?!!nicht!!?/i?!! negates the adjective = !!?i?!!nicht gut!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!!!?i?!!nicht!!?/i?!! negates the verb = !!?i?!!nicht kennen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!negates the noun with an indefinite article = !!?i?!!ein!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! =!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!kein!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! The following words you have learned: !!?i?!!unberechtigt, unlustig, unsicher, unzuverlässig!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. They are negated adjectives:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Not all adjectives can be negated with !!?i?!!un-.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!instead!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!instead!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!or the opposite: !!?i?!!kurz!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!instead!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!or the opposite: !!?i?!!jung, neu!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Derivatives / Ableitungen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!A single word can be formed into new words by adding a final syllable/suffix. Infinitives and unconjugated verbs omit the !!?i?!!-en !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!ending. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! Verb = title of a person!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Object = title of a person!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Preposition = title of a person = adjective!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Compound nouns / Komposita!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Compound nouns are words which consist of at least two words joined together. Most compound nouns are determining compounds. They are so called because the first word determines/qualifies the second word. Noun = exact determination unspecifiedspecified!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The -!!?i?!!s-!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! between two word parts (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Frühling!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! + !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Zeit!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!) has no meaning, it merely helps in the pronunciation of the word. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! The gender of the compound noun is determined by the last word, hence:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The adjective as an attribute!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!You already know many adjectives. We used them in combination with !!?i?!!sein!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. The adjective is however mainly used as a noun attribute and must be declined in combination with the noun. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! Compare:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Declension of adjectives!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The degrees of comparison of the adjective!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!After the definite article, all noun endings are alike: !!?i?!!-e!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!, apart form the masculine ending in the accusative, which ist -!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!en!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!After the definite article, the noun endings differ: masc. -!!?i?!!er/-en!!?/i?!!, fem. !!?i?!!-e!!?/i?!!, neuter !!?i?!!-es.!!?/i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The interrogatives welcher/welche/welches!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!With !!?i?!!welch-!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! we can ask about attributes. The interrogative is then declined like an adjective.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Look once again at the accusative table in lesson 6: Singular: The feminine and neuter accusative forms have the same endings as those of the nominative. Only the masculine takes the !!?i?!!-en !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!ending.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!Plural: All words take the -!!?i?!!e!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! ending in the nominative and in the accusative.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The football match / Das Fußballspiel!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The football match has a special vocabulary. There are players (!!?i?!!Spieler!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!), also known as football players (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Fußballspieler!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!). They want to kick the ball (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Ball!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!) or the football (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Fußball!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!) into the goal (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Tor!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!)!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!,!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! of course into the opponent’s goal (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!das gegnerische Tor!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!). The goalkeeper(!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Torhüter !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!or!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! Torwart!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!)!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!stands in the goal. In front of the goal is the penalty area (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Strafraum!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!). Then there is the referee (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Schiedsrichter!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!), who blows the whistle, and the linesmen (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Linienrichter!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!) who raise their flags, if certain rules are broken. For example when there is an offside (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Abseits)!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. Don’t ask what offside is! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! You only have to learn this special vocabulary if you love football. However, it is necessary to know how the words are formed, because the rules for this apply to every word.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The modal verb wollen !!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In addition to the modal verbs you have already learned !!?i?!!möchten!!?/i?!! and !!?i?!!müssen!!?/i?!! (lesson 3), !!?i?!!können!!?/i?!! (lesson 5) and !!?i?!!dürfen!!?/i?!! (lesson 8), you will now be introduced to another modal verb: !!?i?!!wollen!!?/i?!!. !!?i?!!wollen!!?/i?!! means to intend!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!to wish!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!more energetic as:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!to demand!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Wollen!!?/i?!! can also be used like all modal verbs as a full verb and as an auxiliary verb. as an auxiliary!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!as a full verb!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The conjugation of wollen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Word formation!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Did you notice and understand the compound nouns in text 44?!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!-!!?i?!!n-!!?/i?!! in between!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!-!!?i?!!s!!?/i?!!- in between!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The infinitive ending -!!?i?!!en!!?/i?!! is omitted. We can also say:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The base words are determined, that is to say more exactly specified, by the word placed first. They are determining compounds. However, if we break up the compound noun and place the first part of the compound after the base word, we have a word group with a case (genitive) or a preposition linked to the base word.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!linked to a case!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!linked to the preposition !!?i?!!zum!!?/i?!!; from: !!?i?!!zu (de)m!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!In this way words can be more specific without the need to form a compound. Sometimes a compound is not possible so that the word group remains the only form of expression.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Now we come to two further grammatical elements: to the attribute which you already know as an adjective with nouns, and to the dative case.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The attributive / Das Attribut!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The attributive is an attribute most frequently linked to a noun. It qualifies a noun more precisely – like the first part of a compound noun. You already know some attributive word groups such as!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!An adjective as an attribute!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Here nouns are more exactly qualified by the adjective through the attribution of a characteristic.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Prepositional word groups as attributes!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The nouns in the above-mentioned word groups are more precisely characterised by the postpositive prepositional word groups:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The dative / Der Dativ!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!We would like to remind you that there are 4 grammatical cases in German: 1st case – the nominative / Nominativ 2nd case – the genitive / Genitiv 3rd case – the dative / Dativ 4th case – the accusative / Akkusativ You already know the nominative and the accusative. We will now introduce you to the next case, the dative. Compare: definiteindefinitenegative!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The rule:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Dative complements!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Many verbs require a complement, if the statement of the sentence is to be complete. This can be an accusative complement (compare lessons 6 and 9) or a dative complement. For example I can say:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!But the statement is so general that it cannot be regarded as complete. Therefore one expects a complement (object).!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The interrogative for a dative complement is !!?i?!!wem.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Dative complements + preposition!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!We will remind you of lesson 9 and establish once again: a sentence can contain verb complements, which are linked to the verb by the case or by a preposition.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!linked to the verb by the case!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!linked to the verb by the preposition, the preposition requires the dative.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Verbs with dative prepositions!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Dative prepositions!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Take care to note which preposition is used because the case of the noun or of the pronoun is determined by the preposition.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Prepositions, which always require the dative!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Some prepositions merge with the article !!?i?!!dem !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!or !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!der.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!This is only possible with the dative prepositions in the following instances:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In lesson 9 it was explained that some prepositions can take the accusative or the dative. The change of cases will be dealt with later – in the lesson on expressions of place.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Prepositions, which can take the dative or the accusative!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Questions and interrogatives / Fragen und Fragewörter!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!If you don’t understand something, then ask someone who can explain everything. If you don’t ask, then you won’t learn. Hence, it is necessary to learn how to ask questions in German. Don’t be afraid to ask because: there are no stupid questions. There are only stupid answers. You already know the interrogatives!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Do you remember?!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about a person in the nominative, about the subject of the sentence: !!?i?!!der Deutschlehrer!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about an object, a thing in the nominative, about the subject of the sentence: !!?i?!!ein Buch!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about an attribute in the nominative: !!?i?!!unser Buch!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about an accusative complement: !!?i?!!den Deutschlehrer!!?/i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about a dative complement: !!?i?!!dir.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! Now you will learn some new interrogatives.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Questions about circumstances, conditions, facts!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about the reason, the cause of a thing, an event, or the behaviour of a person!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the word which corresponds to !!?i?!!warum!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about a location, a place!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the word which corresponds to !!?i?!!wo!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about the purpose of an object, of an action!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the word which corresponds to !!?i?!!wozu!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about a prepositional complement!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the word which corresponds to !!?i?!!wovon!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about a prepositional complement!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the word which corresponds to !!?i?!!woran!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about a prepositional complement!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the word which corresponds to !!?i?!!worüber!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asks about the purpose!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the word which corresponds to !!?i?!!wofür!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Interrogatives!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The 1st part of many interrogatives is !!?i?!!wo!!?/i?!!-, the 2nd part is a preposition. If the preposition begins with a vowel, !!?i?!!-r- !!?/i?!!is placed in between!!?i?!!.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Corresponding words!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The 1st part is !!?i?!!da-,!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! the 2!!?/i?!!nd part is a preposition. The rule is the same here: If the preposition begins with a vowel, -!!?i?!!r- !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!is placed in between!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Questions about people or institutions!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Accusative or dative complements with a preposition can name a person or an institution. The questions about these complements vary: The preposition of the complement is placed before !!?i?!!wen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!? / !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!wem!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!?!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! prepositional accusative complements – preposition + !!?i?!!wen!!?/i?!!?!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!prepositional dative complements – preposition + !!?i?!!wem!!?/i?!!?!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Questions requiring an answer in a sentence and questions requiring a decision!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!You certainly know that: there are questions which requi!!?i?!!re !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!an answer in a complete sentence, and questions which can be answered with a !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Ja!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! or !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Nein!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. Questions requiring a full sentence are mostly answered with what is directly asked.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Questions requiring an answer in a sentence!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Questions requiring a decision!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!For revision: accusative and dative complements!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Accusative complements!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Dative complements!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!For revision: prepositional complements!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!3 special words: ganz, vielleicht, wahrscheinlich!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The word !!?i?!!ganz !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!has various meanings. Whoever uses it wrongly says perhaps the opposite to what he meant to say. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! !!?i?!!Ganz!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! can mean:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!It says in text 47:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Both words express that what the sentence says is not completely certain.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!yes or no? It is open ended, is not stated.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!It is possible, but not certain!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The modal verb sollen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!You have already learnt that modal verbs modify the sense in which something will happen.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!it is desired!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!it is possible!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!expressing an intention!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!it is necessary!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!it is allowed!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The modal verb !!?i?!!sollen !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!means: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!1. something is required/requisition 2. something is supposed to take place/supposition!!?i?!!. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! This is how it is formed in the present tense:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!requisition!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!requisition!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!supposition!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!requisition!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!supposition!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!supposition!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!brauchen with zu + verb!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!You already know how to form sentences:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!However: !!?i?!!brauchen!!?/i?!! can also be linked with an infinitive verb + !!?i?!!zu!!?/i?!!. !!?i?!!Brauchen!!?/i?!! then means !!?i?!!müssen!!?/i?!!:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The demonstrative pronouns derselbe, dieselbe, dasselbe!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!This means: !!?i?!!einer/eine/eines!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! are exactly like !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!der/die/das andere!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!, both things are identical.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The demonstrative pronouns are declined like the articles:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Expressions of place (!!?i?!!wo!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!?), of direction (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!woher!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!? !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!=) and of distance (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!wie weit!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!?) are put in the dative case. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!Expressions of direction (!!?i?!!wohin!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!? =!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!) are put in the accusative or the dative (with !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!zu!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!nach!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!). !!?/i?!!Thus:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Dative/accusative prepositions for expressions of location!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!There are a number of prepositions available to us which represent expressions of location in the accusative and in the dative. These are: (compare lesson 11)!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!These prepositions are used with the dative, if someone asks the question: !!?i?!!wo!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!?!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! They are used with the accusative, if someone asks the question: !!?i?!!wohin!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!?!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! Examples:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The article can be merged with: !!?i?!!an, in, über, unter, vor!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!There are corresponding words joined with the interrogatives !!?i?!!wo, wohin, woher!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!, which can be used for statements of analogy. They contain the same elements as the interrogatives, except that !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!wo!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is replaced by !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!da!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. Compare lesson 12.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Cautious statements!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The sentence !!?i?!!Die Deutschen können nicht mit Zahlen umgehen !!?/i?!! is an absolutely categorical observation. Whoever wants to reduce the absoluteness of the statement, places the following phrases before the statement !!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In this way the statement is expressed more cautiously. That is Alina’s intention in text 57. She says:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!She is not certain that it is true. Isabella contradicts her just as cautiously, when she says:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The small, but important word zu!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!How is !!?i?!!zu!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! used?!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!a)in the meaning: to close!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!b)in the meaning: more as!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!c)as a verb prefix, usually with a different meaning !!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!to close!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!to avow d)as an element of the infinitive!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The infinitive with zu / Der Infinitiv mit zu!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The unconjugated, so-called infinitive verb can be combined with !!?i?!!zu!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! thus producing its own special word group: the infinitive with !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!zu.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! This word group can be extended with other sentence elements; from which the infinitive sentence is yielded. (The conjugated verb is called!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!: finites Verb!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!.)!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Simple infinitive with zu:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The infinitive with !!?i?!!zu !!?/i?!!is extended by a word or several words and usually separated from the sentence by a comma.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Extended infinitive with zu:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The extended infinitive with !!?i?!!zu!!?/i?!! (infinitive sentence) is a complement. To illustrate this function, one can replace the extended infinitive with a general word, for example either !!?i?!!es, das!!?/i?!! or !!?i?!!daran, darauf!!?/i?!! or other similar words.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The verbs !!?i?!!nehmen, geben, holen, bringen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! show movement, especially a movement in which a person A, a person B and a thing X are participating.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!!!?i?!!Nehmen !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!and !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!geben!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! are irregular verbs. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Bringen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is only regular in the present tense.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Geben !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!is a regular verb.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Derivatives: adjectives and nouns!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Many words allow for new words to be derived from them. For example the titles of people dealt with earlier: !!?i?!!Ausland =!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! Ausländer, Berlin =!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! Berliner =!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! Berlinerin!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! (compare lesson 2), !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!spiel(en) =!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! Spieler, Fußball =!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! Fußballer!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! (compare lesson 10). All the following examples come from the vocabulary sections in lessons 1 – 14.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Adjectives are also formed through derivation. The meaning of most of these derivative adjectives corresponds to that of the word from which it was derived, but sometimes the derivation results in a consiberable difference in meaning, for example with !!?i?!!kostbar.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! The most common derivative endings (suffixes) are !!?i?!!-lich, -ig, -isch,!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! whereas -!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!sam!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! !!?i?!!-bar!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! are less common endings.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! As a derivative of a verb !!?i?!!-bar!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! mostly means: it is possible: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!machbar!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! = it is possible to do it!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! !!?i?!!-sam!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! mostly means: special: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!bedeutsam!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! = it has a special meaning !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! Examples!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The most common derivative endings (suffixes) are -ung, -heit, -igkeit, -nis, -schaft. Whereas -tum and -sal are less common endings. Please note with regard to the grammatical gender of the noun: Derivatives ending in -ung, -heit, - igkeit, -schaft are feminine. Derivatives ending in -tum are neuter; exceptions: der Irrtum, der Reichtum. Examples!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The indefinite pronoun man!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The word !!?i?!!man!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is used as a pronoun for an undesignated person or group of persons. It occurs only in the nominative and is always singular.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The word was originally derived from !!?i?!!Mann!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!, but is rarely linked to the word nowadays. In recent times the women’s movement has partly enabled !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!frau !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!to be written in place of !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!man!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!, for example:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The indefinite pronouns jemand and niemand!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Just like !!?i?!!man, jemand!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is also an undesignated person. However, in contrast to !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!man,!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!jemand!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is always a single person, not a group of people. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Jemand!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is a person, who someone cannot name or doesn’t want to name.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Jemand is!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! said!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!a) when one doesn’t know who the person is or b) when one knows, but doesn’t want to name the person The negation of !!?i?!!jemand!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!niemand.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! The indefinite pronoun !!?i?!!niemand !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!appeared in lesson 3. We used it as a family name and this caused a misunderstanding.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The impersonal es!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!This word is known to you as a personal pronoun in the 3rd person singular:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!The word!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! es !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!can also represent something impersonal, something without a real equivalent. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!The impersonal !!?i?!!es!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is always singular and can be the subject of a sentence. !!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!You have already learned this use of !!?i?!!es!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! in some phrases:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!This !!?i?!!es!!?/i?!! doesn’t mean anything, but without it the sentence is incomplete, because it lacks a subject. This !!?i?!!es!!?/i?!! is the substitute for the missing subject; the subject is missing because it can’t be named.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The verb lassen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The verb !!?i?!!lassen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is an important word because of its semantics and it is used very often. It is used like the modal verbs, in other words: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!lassen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is the finite verb in the sentence and the infinitive verb is added.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The conjugation of !!?i?!!lassen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!present – regular:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Note: !!?i?!!Lassen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! can also be used as a full verb and the participle for this is !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!gelassen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Sometimes lassen is used wrongly: *Ich habe es liegen gelassen. But don’t let yourself be disturbed by this!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The reflexive pronoun selbst!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The stressed reflexive pronoun !!?i?!!selbst!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! emphasises the identity:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The unstressed reflexive pronoun !!?i?!!selbst!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! means: even.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Expressions of time!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Everything occurs in space and time. Space is covered by the expressions of place, and time by expressions of time/temporal expressions. Expressions of time are words or groups of words about which you can ask:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the timepoint of a process!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the end of a process!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the beginning of a process!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!the duration The semantics of the timepoint (!!?i?!!wann!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!?) and duration (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!wie lange!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!?) are easy to understand; for example!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!: heute, von 8 bis 12 Uhr.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!The end of a process (!!?i?!!bis wann!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!?) and the beginning of a process (!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!seit wann!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!?) are easy to recognise because they are indicated by the prepositions !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!bis!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!seit!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Temporal subordinate clauses!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!A statement of time can also take the form of a subordinate clause. In such cases the conjunctions are for example:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Derived expressions of time!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Temporal nouns are made into short expressions of time by adding an -!!?i?!!s !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!ending.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Derivations: verb = noun!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The meaning of many words can be deduced immediately, if you compare the verb and the noun. The one can be derived from the other, although mostly the noun is derived from the verb. Besides the derivation of nouns with the endings !!?i?!!-ung, -nis!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and others (compare lesson 10); sometimes the vowel changes as a result. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! derivation with !!?i?!!-ung!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The imperative: command/instruction / Der Imperativ!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The imperative is always a main clause. It does not appear in subordinate clauses. The imperative sentence is ended with an exclamation mark (!). The imperative exists only in the 2nd person singular and plural and with the polite form !!?i?!!Sie!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! There are five possible ways to express the imperative.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!1. The direct imperative is formed with the present tense!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The singular of the imperative corresponds to the 2nd person singular and the polite form !!?i?!!Sie:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Note: Irregular verbs sometimes have a different vowel in the 2nd person singular to that of the infinitive:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The plural of the imperative corresponds to the 2nd person plural:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!2. Formation with the present tense + man!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!For example in recipes and operating manuals:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!3. Formation with the past participle!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!4. Formation with the infinitive!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The imperative is a strict command. In the spoken language the tone can be softened or heightened. If you want to soften the tone of the command so that it is understood more as a request and not as a strict order, !!?i?!!bitte!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! must be added. The exclamation mark can be omitted, but only in the 1!!?/i?!!st and 4th types of formation.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!5. Other forms for imperative sentences!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!– with sollen:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!– with lassen:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Ordinal numbers!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Ordinal numbers indicate a sequence: !!?i?!!der erste, der zweite, der dritte ...!!?/i?!! They are declined like adjectives. How to form them: 1 – 19 = number + !!?i?!!-te!!?/i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!exceptions:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!numbers over 20 = number + !!?i?!!-ste!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The verb/auxiliary verb werden!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The word !!?i?!!werden!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! can be a full verb or an auxiliary verb. We will concentrate here on its use as a full verb. The explanation of !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!werden!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! as an auxiliary will come later.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! As a full verb !!?i?!!werden!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! can be combined with an adjective or with a noun. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!In the present tense !!?i?!!werden!!?/i?!! always has a future meaning. In the present perfect – like all verbs in the present perfect – it expresses the past.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Word formation: Verb and noun phrases!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!It says in text 68:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Standing opposite to each other are:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The noun phrase sounds more imposing than the verb. They are identical expressions nonetheless. In principal the one expression can be exchanged for the other. This applies to !!?i?!!erfüllen,!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! only if the reflexive form of the verb is used: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!sich erfüllen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! It says in text 68:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!not reflexive!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!a sentence without meaning In the vocabulary lists, which you have learned, there were completely identical verbs and noun phrases to be found:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The replacement of the noun phrase with the verb is in some instances contingent upon the addition of a word or complement or not possible at all:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!!!?i?!!hungern!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! is a more intensive condition than !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Hunger haben.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!!!?i?!!die Rolle!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!, which is derived from !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!rollen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!, has a separate, different meaning in a phrase: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!eine Rolle spielen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! = it is important.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Note: Before you decide to change a verb = into a noun phrase, look in a dictionary!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Causal expressions/causal clauses!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Causal expressions and causal subordinate clauses name – something general – the reason, the cause for a thing. Apart from the simple, direct reason, there are also special aspects concerning the reason: the results, the condition, the purpose, and the disregarded/insufficient reason. The causal elements of statements occur as phrases (causal expressions) or as subordinate clauses (causal clauses) or as infinitive sentences.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Causal clauses are introduced for example with!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!These introduce subordinate clauses, whose verb parts are placed at the end of the clause with last of all the finite verb. The !!?i?!!wenn!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!-clauses can have a causal or a temporal meaning.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! !!?i?!!Denn!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! introduces causal clauses, which are formed like a main clause: the finite verb is in the 2!!?/i?!!nd position and follows the subject.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Word formation: Adjectives with the endings -los, -voll and -bar!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Adjectives with the ending -voll can be found in this lesson. The ending !!?i?!!-voll!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! gives the adjective the meaning !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!mit viel!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Some adjectives with the ending -bar are already known to you:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The ending !!?i?!!-bar!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! gives almost all adjectives the meaning: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!man kann es!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! + verb. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!The prefix !!?i?!!un-!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! brings about the opposite, negative meaning: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!man kann es nicht!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! + verb.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!But other meanings!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Diminutives!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!We can give people and processes a value: with the ending -!!?i?!!chen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!with the ending –!!?i?!!lein!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The genitive / Der Genitiv!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The 4th case, which we must explain, is the genitive. You are already familiar with the other three: nominative (Nominativ), accusative (Akkusativ) and dative (Dativ). Now the genitive is added to the list. The genitive can combine with a verb or a noun. Nowadays the genitive case is not so often found in connection with verbs. Nouns and pronouns in the genitive, which are linked to a verb, produce a genitive complement. The genitive case is found in a great number of nouns. It serves to couple attributive phrases and genitive attributes with nouns and sometimes with other words.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Genitive complement!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Genitive attribute / Das Genitiv-Attribut !!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The formation of the genitive!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!definiteindefinitenegative possessive!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The characteristic endings of the genitive article are -!!?i?!!s !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!and -!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!r!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The characteristic endings of the genitive pronoun are -(!!?i?!!e!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!)!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!s!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and -(!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!e!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!)!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!r!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!For comparison:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Genitive substitutes: von + Dativ!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The genitive attribute is also used with !!?i?!!von!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! + the dative case!!?/i?!!, especially: with the indefinite + plural!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The -!!?i?!!s!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! ending often appears in words which are derived from nouns. The -!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!s!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! ending is the sign of an original genitive function, for example in time expressions: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!morgens, abends!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!, but also in words like !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!anfangs, teils!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The preceding genitive attribute!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The genitive attribute is generally placed first in names and formed with the -!!?i?!!s!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! ending. The preceding genitive is also required, if it represents a label, which is used in a family like a name, for example: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!Lisa, Vater, Oma, Meier!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Genitival prepositions!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Genitival prepositions are very numerous, but aren’t used very often in the everyday language. They occur more often in official and specialist language. Many genitival prepositions were originally nouns or noun phrases as the “-s” ending indicates. Here is a selection of genitival prepositions:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!A number of genitival prepositions have a locative meaning:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!asiede!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!outside!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!within!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Verb–noun pairings!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In the vocabulary sections of the previous lessons there appear numerous verbs from which nouns are formed, and nouns in which you have certainly recognised the verb. This lesson also contains some new verb-noun pairings.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Declension of the adjective!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Nouns like to be linked with adjectives. There are some examples in the first lesson. Do you remember them? !!?i?!!Das sind internationale Wörter.!!?/i?!! In lesson 10 you learned about adjectives in the nominative and in the accusative, and in lesson 11 the dative of !!?i?!!ein!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!kein!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! was added = !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!einem/einer, keinem/keiner!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. We will repeat what you already know and complete the declension.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!A summary of the declension of the adjective!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The past participle as an adjective!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Many past participles can be used as adjectives. They let themselves be declined like adjectives. Examples:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Ways to determine a word more precisely with the attribute!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Attributes, which determine a thing, a person, a process, or a condition more precisely so as to differentiate it from other elements of a similar kind, can occur in various forms. You have already learned them. We will put them all together so that the principle of applying an attribute is clear to see. The more precise defining of a word is made by: a) the adjective!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!b) the genitival noun!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!c) the determining part of a compound noun!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!d) the prepositional phrase!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Adjectives used as nouns!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In text 83 there is an adjective which was made into a noun by means of a fixed rule:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!For this derivation the rule is: After !!?i?!!alles, etwas, manches, nichts, nur, viel, wenig!!?/i?!! all adjectives become nouns. After !!?i?!!alles!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! manches!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! the adjective used as a noun takes the ending -!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!e!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In the following instances the ending is -!!?i?!!es!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!When combined with a preposition which requires the dative, adjectives used as nouns are regular in their declension.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The word order of the sentence frame: Der Satzrahmen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!You remember: the 1st position in the sentence/simple statement can be occupied by any sentence part, while the 2nd position is meant for the finite verb, and all the other elements follow afterwards. If the verb is divided into two parts by the present perfect form or through the combination with a modal verb, the finite element on the one hand and all the remaining verb parts on the other, form a frame around the remaining parts of the sentence.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Sentence frames in normal statements!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!1st position2nd positionother parts of the sentence!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!1st position2nd positionother parts of the sentence Subject frame partframe part!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The important parts of a sentence are placed at the end of the sentence or before the last part of the frame. They are arranged according to the significance of the word and of the information. Nouns are more important than other words, for example more important than the little words !!?i?!!gern!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!immer!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. The significant word is stressed when it is placed at the end of the sentence.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! We can also say:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Note: If the subject is placed within the frame, it immediately follows the finite element. The subjects in the examples are: !!?i?!!viele Menschen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!ich.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Sentence frames in the interrogative sentence!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!1st position2nd positionother parts of the sentence finite element frame part frame part with an interrogative:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!without an interrogative:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Sentence frames in the subordinate clause!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!1st position2nd positionother parts of the sentence finite elementfinite frame part frame part with a conjunction!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!without a conjunction!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In interrogatives sentences with an introductory word/conjunction the frame is formed by the conjunction and the finite element; the infinite verb and the past participle are placed directly before the end of the frame. In interrogative sentences with conjunctions the word order is the same as in normal statements/main clauses.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The relative clause / Der Relativsatz!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In the last lesson of the 2nd part you learned the various ways to define a word more precisely: with adjectives, nouns, prepositional phrases, and with compound nouns with a defining part. A word can also be more precisely defined through the use of a clause, of a relative clause. Examples:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The relative clause is mainly placed directly after the word in the sentence, which is to be defined more precisely: !!?i?!!Fluss, der/dem/auf dem!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The relative pronoun!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The relation to the word, which is to be defined, is brought about through the relative pronoun. The following function as such: the definite article / !!?i?!!der bestimmte Artikel!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!the definite article with a preposition / !!?i?!!der bestimmte Artikel + Präposition!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!was, wo, wie!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! The definite article is declined whatever way the relative clause demands. If the relative pronoun belongs to a preposition, the preposition stands before the article:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!and undeclined:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!There is a special rule for the use of !!?i?!!was!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! as a relative pronoun:!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!Relative clauses used as more precise definition of !!?i?!!alles, etwas, manches, nichts, nur, viel,!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!wenig!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! – standing alone adjectives or adjectives used as nouns – always have the relative pronoun !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!was!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. This also applies to the demonstrative !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!das.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!Examples:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The position of the relative clause!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The relative clause is connected to the word which is to be defined, and cannot therefore be placed at the start of the sentence. It is either postpositive or has an intermediate position postpositive!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!intermediate!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Relative clauses can also form a sequence: postpositive!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!intermediate!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The position of the verbal elements in the relative clause!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The relative clause is a subordinate clause. It is introduced by a relative pronoun and ends with the finite part of the verb. The position of the verbal elements in the relative clause is exactly the same as in subordinate clauses, which are introduced by a conjunction.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Ambiguity!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!If we needed our own description for every object, concept, characteristic, and process, the vocabulary would be so extensive that we could not comprehend it, and we would have great difficulty in communicating or wouldn’t be able to communicate at all. Ambiguity helps us out of this difficulty. A word can have several meanings. The context, in which something is said, or the text which surrounds a word, help to clarify the meaning. In other words, we understand what is meant because we always find ourselves in a speaking context or we are reading a larger text. However there also misunderstandings, which arise out of ambiguity. And people like to tell jokes which rest on ambiguity. The speaker means one thing, while the listener understands another. You encountered some examples of this in the past lessons. Also the jokes from texts 88 and 89 depend on ambiguity.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!a prescription for medicine!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!a recipe for a meal Ambiguity is a trap for everyone, who learns a foreign language. You can only avoid falling into the trap, if you pay attention to the text and the situation or when in doubt you look in a dictionary.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!A small, but important word: erst!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!!!?i?!!Erst !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!can have the following meanings:!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! !!?i?!!zuerst!!?/i?!!/first!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!general qualification of a part of a sentence!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!temporal qualification!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!quantitative qualification!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Note: do not mistake !!?i?!!erst!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! for the ordinal number !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!erster/e/es!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!Compare:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Verbs with prefixes / Verben mit Präfixen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In German there are many verbs with a prefix. For example:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Certain prefixes are permanently connected to the verb, others are separated from the verb in the present tense and in the past tense (see lesson 22) and form a sentence frame together with the verb; as a result the prefix stands at the end of the sentence.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Note: Due to the prefiguration the meaning of the verbs can change markedly.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Verbs with fixed prefixes / Verben mit festen Präfixen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The fixed prefixes (feste Präfixe) of verbs are!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!and the negating prefix miss- These prefixes remain in all conjugations of the verb. There is no !!?i?!!ge!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!- prefix in the past participle!!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Verbs with separable prefixes / Verben mit unfesten/trennbaren Präfixen!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Verbs with separable prefixes (mit trennbaren/unfesten Präfixen) are numerous. There are prefixes, which also belong to the language as words in their own right. In the spoken language they are recognisable by the stress put on the prefix. The separable prefixes (trennbare/unfeste Präfixe) are:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The !!?i?!!ge-!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! of the past participle and the !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!zu-!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! in infinitive clauses are placed after the prefix.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Two small, but important words: schon and nun!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The word schon!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Schon !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!can have the following meanings:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!already!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The past tense or preterite / Das Imperfekt!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The past can be expressed by the present perfect with !!?i?!!haben!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! or !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!sein!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and the past participle of the verb: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!ich habe gehört, ich bin gegangen!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. The past tense is another possibility, the usual form for all actions in the past: !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!ich hörte, ich ging!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!. The forms of the past are numerous. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!! We must distinguish between: regular/weak and irregular/strong verbs.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The past of regular/weak verbs !!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Be aware of the separable prefixes, which are separated from the verb root in the past, and the verbs, which end in !!?i?!!-ten!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! or !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!-den!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and require an -!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!e!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!- before past endings.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The past of modal verbs!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The modal verbs are very regular, but do without the Umlaut -!!?i?!!ö!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!- or -!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!ü!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!- in the past tense.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Irregular verbs will be dealt with in the next lesson. Three such verbs in the past tense tense have already appeared in this lesson:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The imperfect of haben and sein!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Haben!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!sein!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! as independent verbs in the past tense:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!without verbs with prefixes, because they behave like the corresponding verbs without prefixes. all foreign words ending in !!?i?!!-ieren!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! are regular/weak verbs.!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!Some verbs with separable prefixes are listed because the corresponding base verb has not been introduced as yet. seldom used verbs are left out of the list regular/weak verbs are recognisable by the participle: (!!?i?!!ge!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!-) ... -!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!t; !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! compare the vocabulary sections in each lesson.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Ambiguous verbs and fixed phrases!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!You know already: many words are ambiguous/polysemic. This is true not only for nouns, but also verbs. Ambiguity occurs for example in verbs, which either stand alone or appear in fixed phrases. Examples:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The past tense/preterite / Das Imperfekt!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In lesson 23 we explained the past forms of regular/weak verbs. Now we complete the past forms and introduce the irregular/strong verbs. (The terms weak verbs and strong verbs are found in many grammar books). Irregular verbs are quite numerous. As no clear rule can be given for them, in contrast to the regular verbs, the past forms must be learned together with the infinitive and the past participle. The best way is as follows:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The irregular verbs are listed in the vocabulary sections as follows:!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Past tense of irregular/strong verbs!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!As you see the endings repeat themselves in the 2nd person singular and plural forms. The 1st person and 3rd person singular take no ending. The difficulty lies in the change of the verb root (vowel) and these can be very different.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Imperfect of irregular verbs/mixed forms!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Some verbs do not behave exactly like regular verbs or irregular verbs. They are mixed forms: They have a -!!?i?!!t-!!?/i?!!!!?i?!!ending– like regular verbs!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!They change their root vowel– like irregular verbs!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!The auxiliary verbs !!?i?!!sein, haben!!?/i?!!!!?i?!! and !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!werden !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!also belong to the mixed forms in the past.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!List of irregular verbs in lessons 1 to 24.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!Verbs with separable prefixes are formed in the same way as verbs without prefixes. We don’t include them in the vocabulary lists.!!?br?!!!!?br?!!
!!?br?!!!!?br?!!In alphabetical order!!?br?!!!!?br?!!

Also sentences introduced by !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!trotzdem !!?/i?!!!!?i?!!state a contrast, but the statements change position. !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!!!?i?!! !!?/i?!!
